choices.text: 1 and 3 are true; 2 and 4 are false
1 and 2 are true; 3 and 4 are false
1, 3 and 4 are true; 2 is false
Only 3 is true; all others are false

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Hormone Response Elements (HREs) are true?
1. HREs are specific DNA sequences that bind activated hormone-receptor complexes
2. HREs are located on messenger RNA and bind steroid hormone receptors
3. HREs serve as high-affinity binding sites that facilitate transcription activation
4. HREs are formed by liganded mRNA-protein complexes in the cytoplasm
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The lipophilic group I hormones diffuse through the plasma membrane of all cells but only encounter their specific, high-affinity intracellular receptors in target cells. These receptors can be located in the cytoplasm or the nucleus of target cells.
  • The hormone-receptor complex first undergoes an activationreaction.
  • The activated receptor moves into the nucleus and binds with high affinity to a specific DNA sequence called the hormone response element (HRE). (Statement 1 is true)
  • The DNA-bound, liganded receptor serves as a high-affinity binding target for one or more coactivator proteins, and accelerated gene transcription. (Statement 3 is true)
  • By selectively affecting gene transcription and the consequent production of appropriate target mRNAs, the amounts of specific proteins are changed, and metabolic processes are influenced.
  • HREs are not located on mRNA, nor do they bind mRNA or form in the cytoplasm.Their function is genomic, not post-transcriptional. (Statement 2 is false, Statement 4 is false)

choices.text: 1, 3, and 4 are true; 2 is false
1 and 2 are true; 3 and 4 are false

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding Group II hormone signal transduction?
1.Cyclic GMP acts as a second messenger for some Group II hormones
2.Group II hormones bind intracellular receptors to initiate transcription
3.Phosphatidylinositol and Ca2+ serve as second messengers
4. Receptors for Group II hormones are present on the cell surface
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cyclic GMP (cGMP), generated via guanylyl cyclase, functions as a second messenger for certain Group II hormones. (Statement 1 is true)
  • Ca²⁺ and phosphatidylinositol are classical second messengers in Group II hormone signaling. (Statement 3 is true)
  • Group II hormones do not bind intracellular receptors. They act via surface receptors and use Intracellular second messengers. (Statement 2 is false and 4 is true)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Group I hormones?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Group I hormones are lipophilic (fat-soluble) hormones like steroids, thyroid hormones, and calcitriol. (Option A ruled out)
  • They are bound to transport proteins in circulation. (Option C ruled out)
  • Due to their stability and binding with plasma proteins, they exhibit a long half-life (ranging from hours to days).
  • They cross the cell membrane and bind to intracellular receptors, forming hormone-receptor complexes that regulate gene transcription (Option B ruled out).

questions.text: Which of the following hormones inhibit Adenylyl cyclase and reduce the production of cAMP?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Intracellular cAMP regulation is a central aspect of signal transduction for Group II hormones.
  • These hormones interact with cell surface receptors, leading to either activation or inhibition of the enzyme adenylyl cyclase, which catalyses the conversion of ATP to cyclic AMP (cAMP), a secondary messenger.
  • Somatostatin binds to its receptor and activates Gi protein, which in turn inhibits adenylyl cyclase, hence decreasing cAMP.
  • Calcitonin, Glucagon, and ADH interact with Gs proteins, leading to activation of adenylyl cyclase ,thus Increases cAMP. (Options B, C and D ruled out)

questions.text: Match the following toxins with their actions on G-protein α subunits:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Heterotrimeric G-proteins composed of α, β, and γ subunits.
  • Since the α subunit in Gs differs from that in Gi, the proteins, which are distinct gene products, are designated αs and αi. The α subunits bind guanine nucleotides. The β and γ subunits are likely always associated (βγ) and appear to function predominantly as a heterodimer.
  • The αs subunit has intrinsic GTPase The active form, αs-GTP, is inactivated on hydrolysis of the GTP to GDP; the trimeric Gs complex (αβγ) is then reformed and is ready for another cycle of activation.
  • Cholera toxin catalyses ADP-ribosylation of Gαs, inhibiting its GTPase activity, resulting in irreversible activation.
  • Pertussis toxin modifies Gαi-2, preventing its dissociation from βγ, hence preventing its action.
  • GTP binding activates Gαs reversibly.
  • GDP binding causes Gαs to reassociate with βγ, inactivating the G protein.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules activates protein kinase A?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In eukaryotic cells, cyclic AMP (cAMP) binds to protein kinase A (PKA), a heterotetramer composed of two regulatory (R) and two catalytic (C) subunits (R2C2 complex).
  • In the inactive state, the R subunits inhibit the activity of the C subunits.
  • When four molecules of cAMP bind to the R subunits, it causes dissociation of the R-C complex, thereby releasing the active C subunits.
  • The active C subunits phosphorylate serine or threonine residues on target proteins using ATP as a phosphate donor.
  • This phosphorylation modulates multiple cellular processes depending on the tissue and target proteins involved.

Explanation of other options:

Calcium (Option A): Activates protein kinase C, not protein kinase A.

cGMP (Option B): Activates protein kinase G, not PKA.

ATP (Option D): Serves as a phosphate donor in the kinase reaction but does not activate protein kinase A.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is primarily responsible for terminating the cellular actions of hormones that increase intracellular cAMP concentration?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cellular actions of hormones that increase cAMP (cyclic adenosine monophosphate) levels are terminated by the action of phosphodiesterases (PDEs).
  • These enzymes hydrolyse cAMP to 5'-AMP, thereby stopping the cAMP-dependent signalling cascade.
  • This enzymatic degradation is essential for the rapid turnover of second messengers and for ensuring that cellular responses cease once the hormonal signal is withdrawn.
  • There are at least 11 families of phosphodiesterases with distinct tissue distributions and regulatory properties, and they are often regulated by the very second messengers they degrade, including cAMP.

Explanation of Other options:

Protein kinase (Option A): Protein kinase A is activated by cAMP and is part of the signalling cascade, not responsible for its termination.

Phospholipase (Option C): Involved in other signalling pathways like the IP₃-DAG cascade, not in cAMP breakdown.

Phosphoprotein phosphatase (Option D): Removes phosphate groups from proteins but does not degrade cAMP.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone receptors has intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Insulin receptor is a transmembrane receptor that possesses intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity located in its cytoplasmic domain.
  • Upon insulin binding, autophosphorylation of the receptor occurs, initiating downstream signalling.
  • This class of receptors is shared by growth factor receptors such as EGF and IGF-1, all of which demonstrate intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity.

Explanation of other options:

Glucagon (Option B): Binds to a G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) on the cell surface, which activates adenylate cyclase via Gαs. It does not have tyrosine kinase activity.

Steroid hormones (Option C): These hormones bind to intracellular receptors, which function as ligand-activated transcription factors.

Thyroid hormones (Option D): Bind to nuclear receptors, affecting gene transcription.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones mediate their effect via an increase in cGMP level?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atrial natriuretic peptide mediates their effect via increase in cGMP level
  • Cyclic GMP is made from GTP by the enzyme guanylyl cyclase, which exists in soluble and membrane-bound forms.
  • The atriopeptin, a family of peptides produced in cardiac atrial tissues, causes natriuresis, diuresis, vasodilation, and inhibition of aldosterone These peptides (eg, atrial natriuretic factor) bind to and activate the membrane-bound form of guanylyl cyclase. This increases cGMP and mediates the above effects.
  • A series of compounds, including nitroprusside, nitroglycerin, nitric oxide, sodium nitrite, and sodium azide, all cause smooth muscle relaxation and are potent vasodilators.
  • These agents increase cGMP by activating the soluble form of guanylyl cyclase, and inhibitors of cGMP phosphodiesterase (eg, the drug sildenafil (Viagra) enhance and prolong these responses.
  • The increased cGMP activates cGMP-dependent protein kinase (PKG), which in turn phosphorylates several smooth muscle proteins. This is involved in the relaxation of smooth muscle and vasodilation.

Explanation of other options:

Thyroid hormone (Option A) act via intracellular receptor.

Calcitonin (Option B) acts via a cell surface receptor with cAMP as an intracellular signal.

Gastrin (Option D) functions via a cell surface receptor with second messenger calcium or IP3.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with central obesity, thin extremities, and facial plethora. A particular hormone level remains elevated despite overnight administration of dexamethasone. Which organ system and which hormone are primarily being evaluated by this diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The overnight dexamethasone suppression test is used to assess adrenal cortisol overproduction, and is used for clinical diagnosis of adrenal hyperfunction (Cushing syndrome) or hypofunction (Addison's disease).
  • The secretion of cortisol from the adrenal gland exhibits diurnal variation; serum cortisol levels are highest during the early morning hours and lowest around midnight.
  • Loss of this diurnal variation is one of the earliest signs of adrenal hyperfunction.
  • Measurement of serum cortisol in blood samples drawn at midnight and 8 am is, therefore, useful as a test.
  • A diagnosis of adrenal hyperfunction is confirmed by demonstration of failure of suppression of the early morning concentration of cortisol following the administration of 1 mg dexamethasone (a potent synthetic glucocorticoid) at midnight; this is the dexamethasone suppression test.

Explanation of other options:

Liver, GLP (Option A): Tests used for diagnosis of liver disorders are: serum bilirubin, serum alanine (ALT) and aspartate (AST) aminotransferases, Serum alkaline phosphatase (ALP), serum GGT (Gamma glutamyl transferase), estimation of total proteins, albumin, prothrombin time, estimation of blood ammonia level, etc

Kidney, insulin-like growth factor (Option B): Excretory functions of the kidney are assessed by estimation of serum urea, creatinine and uric acids, clearance tests, proteinuria, etc

Thyroid, thyroxine (Option D): Tests used for disorders involving the thyroid gland are estimation of TSH, T3 & T4 levels, thyroid autoantibodies, etc

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Amyloid, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Amyloids are abnormal, insoluble aggregates of misfolded proteins that accumulate in tissues and organs and are implicated in a variety of human diseases.
  • Their insolubility contributes to their pathogenicity, persistence, and resistance to normal proteolytic degradation.
  • Amyloids are toxic aggregates that result from the misfolding and self-assembly of normally soluble proteins into β-sheet-rich fibrils. (Option A)
  • Amyloids are characteristic of several neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Huntington's disease, and prion diseases (e.g., Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease). (Option C)
  • Amyloid aggregates are refractory to protease degradation, making them persistent and difficult to clear, which leads to chronic cellular stress and tissue damage. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is termed a molecular countdown clock for ageing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Telomeres are repetitive nucleotide sequences (rich in GT repeats) found at the ends of linear eukaryotic chromosomes.
  • They serve as protective caps that prevent chromosomal ends from being recognised as DNA damage.
  • With each round of DNA replication, telomeres progressively shorten because DNA polymerase cannot fully replicate the 3' end of linear chromosomes (end-replication problem). This shortening acts as a molecular countdown clock, signalling cellular ageing.
  • Once telomeres become critically short, cells undergo senescence or apoptosis, preventing further division, a hallmark of the molecular clock theory of ageing.

Explanation of other options:

Reactive oxygen species (ROS) (Option B) are involved in the free radical theory of ageing, which is distinct from the molecular clock theory.

Mitochondria (Option C) are sources of ROS and are implicated in ageing due to oxidative stress, but they are not considered molecular clocks.

Telomerase (Option D) is an enzyme that counteracts telomere shortening, especially in germ cells, stem cells, and cancer cells. It delays the ageing process rather than marking it.

choices.text: Elevated level of plasma glucose promotes the formation of cross-linked protein aggregates
Damage from reactive oxygen species multiplied by tendency of oxygen free radical to multiply via chain reactions
Calorically restricted diets promote lower and more efficient metabolic activity
Damage to mitochondrial genome, leading to deleterious effect on protein of electron transport chain and subsequent ATP generation

questions.text: Which of the following statements most accurately describes an aspect of the metabolic theory of ageing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The metabolic theory of ageing proposes that ageing is linked to the metabolic rate and cumulative oxidative damage.
  • Calorically restricted diets are associated with lower metabolic rates, reduced ROS generation, and enhanced mitochondrial efficiency, all of which delay ageing.

Explanation of other options:

Elevated level of plasma glucose promotes the formation of cross-linked protein aggregates (Option A): Describes the glycation theory of ageing, not the metabolic theory. This is related to AGEs (advanced glycation end products) formation from chronic hyperglycemia.

Damage from reactive oxygen species multiplied by the tendency of oxygen free radicals to multiply via chain reactions (Option B): Refers to the free radical theory of ageing, which focuses on damage from reactive oxygen species (ROS), not the metabolic rate or dietary restriction.

Damage to mitochondrial genome, leading to deleterious effect on the protein of electron transport chain and subsequent ATP generation (Option D): Describes the mitochondrial theory of ageing, where mitochondrial DNA damage leads to defective proteins and impaired ATP generation.

questions.text: All of the following mechanisms can be used to intercept damage caused by Reactive Oxygen species (ROS) and slow ageing, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Caspases are a family of cysteine proteases involved in apoptosis.
  • They do not play a role in scavenging ROS and are not part of antioxidant defence systems.
  • In fact, their activation can promote programmed cell death, often triggered by ROS-induced damage.

Explanation of other options:

Glutathione (Option A) is a cysteine-containing tripeptide that functions as a potent antioxidant. It reacts directly with ROS to convert them into less reactive forms (e.g., water) and helps in detoxifying xenobiotic compounds, thus contributing to the reduction of oxidative stress and ageing.

Superoxide dismutase (SOD) (Option B) converts superoxide radicals to hydrogen peroxide, reducing the damage caused by free radicals. SOD activity has been shown to correlate with increased lifespan in experimental models like Drosophila.

Catalase (Option D) converts hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. By detoxifying hydrogen peroxide, a ROS intermediate, catalase helps prevent oxidative damage and thus may contribute to slower ageing.

questions.text: All of the following are key properties of cancer cells, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cancer cells are characteristically resistant to apoptosis (programmed cell death), a key survival mechanism that allows them to persist despite genetic damage or unfavourable conditions.

Explanation of other options:-

Self-sufficiency in growth signals (Option A): Cancer cells can generate their growth signals or activate pathways that bypass normal growth controls, allowing them to proliferate without external cues.

Insensitivity to anti-growth signals (Option B): Cancer cells resist signals that would normally halt cell division, enabling unchecked growth.

Limitless replicative potential (Option D): Many cancer cells evade normal replicative senescence by activating telomerase, allowing continuous cell division.

Key takeaways:

Six major biologic features of cancer cells:

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical changes can occur in human cancer cell?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Decreased cell adhesion: Cancer cells show reduced expression of cell adhesion molecules (CAMs) such as E-cadherin.
  • This biochemical change facilitates metastasis and tissue invasion, key hallmarks of malignancy.>

Explanation of other options:

Reduced telomerase activity (Option A): Cancer cells show increased telomerase activity to maintain telomere length, enabling unlimited replication and cell immortality.

Activation of tumour suppressor genes (Option B): Cancer cells typically show inactivation of tumour suppressor genes (e.g., p53, Rb), which normally act to restrain cell proliferation.

Inactivation of oncogenes (Option C): Oncogenes are often activated in cancer cells, contributing to transformation and proliferation.

Key takeaways:

Human Cancer cells shows many biochemical and genetic changes like,

questions.text: Radiant damage can lead to following types of DNA damages which leading to cancer, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Formation of purine dimers is not a common or recognised lesion induced by radiation.
  • Purines are more prone to other forms of damage, such as depurination.
  • Ionizing radiation causes a wide range of DNA damage, contributing to mutagenesis and cancer. Key types include:
    • Formation of pyrimidine dimers (Option A) (especially thymine dimers) occurs due to UV radiation. Adjacent thymine bases covalently bond, distorting DNA structure.
    • Elimination of bases (Option C) leads to apurinic/apyrimidinic (AP) sites, following hydrolysis of N-glycosidic bonds. This is a typical result of radiation-induced damage.
    • Cross-linking of DNA strands (Option D), both intra- and inter-strand, as well as with proteins (e.g. histones), is a hallmark of radiation damage. These lesions block replication and transcription.

choices.text: Required Cytochrome P450 for their activation into ultimate carcinogens
Their carcinogenic potential is detected by Guthrie test

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct statement regarding procarcinogens?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Procarcinogens are not carcinogenic in their native form; they must undergo metabolic activation, often by cytochrome P450 enzymes in the endoplasmic reticulum, to form ultimate carcinogens.
  • This bioactivation process is essential for them to become electrophilic species capable of interacting with DNA and initiating carcinogenesis.
  • Procarcinogens include compounds found in tobacco smoke, aflatoxins, and certain dietary and industrial chemicals.

Explanation of other options:

Interact directly with DNA (Option A): Some chemicals, such as mechlorethamine and β-propiolactone, interact directly with DNA and are classified as carcinogens. However, procarcinogens require enzymatic conversion and do not directly interact with DNA in their native form.

Their carcinogenic potential is detected by the Guthrie test (Option C). The Ames test is used to detect carcinogenic potential through bacterial mutation assays. The Guthrie test is used for detecting phenylketonuria, not carcinogenic potential.

Also termed as Oncogenes (Option D): Oncogenes are mutated or overexpressed forms of proto-oncogenes that promote cancer. They are genes, not chemicals like procarcinogens, and do not require enzymatic activation to exert their effect.

choices.text: Ability to induce mutation by chemical carcinogens
Carcinogenic compound which alters epigenetic factors and leading to cancer

questions.text: The Ames assay is primarily used to assess:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Ames test is a biological assay designed to detect mutagenic activity in compounds by measuring the ability of a chemical to cause mutations in the histidine operon of Salmonella typhimurium.
  • If the chemical is mutagenic, it will revert the His⁻ strain to His⁺, enabling growth on histidine-free
  • An additional refinement includes adding mammalian microsomal enzymes (ER) to simulate metabolic activation (helpful in detecting procarcinogens).

Explanation of other options:

Oncogenic properties of certain Viruses (Option A): The Ames test is not used to detect oncogenic properties of viruses. Its primary function is to evaluate the mutagenic potential of chemical compounds.

Carcinogenic compound that alters epigenetic factors and leads to cancer (Option C): Ames assay does not assess epigenetic modifications or regulation; it is a mutagenicity screening test.

Markers for detection of tumour (Option D): Tumour markers like AFP, CEA, PSA, etc., are used for the detection of tumours, not the Ames assay.

questions.text: The presence of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) in serum is detected in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) in serum is detected in cancer of the colon, lung, breast, pancreas, and ovary.

questions.text: The mechanism for action of RAS oncogene involves the following signal transduction molecule:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • RAS is a proto-oncogene that encodes a monomeric G-protein (GTPase) involved in transmitting signals from receptor tyrosine kinases (like EGFR) to downstream MAP kinase signalling pathways.
  • In its normal state, RAS cycles between an active GTP-bound form and an inactive GDP-bound This cycling is tightly regulated by intrinsic GTPase activity.
  • Mutations in RAS impair its ability to hydrolyse GTP, leading to constitutive activation, which promotes uncontrolled cell proliferation.
  • This chronic signalling through the MAPK cascade promotes tumorigenesis.

Explanation of other options:

cAMP (Option A): A second messenger in Gs-protein coupled receptor pathways (e.g., glucagon, epinephrine), not related to RAS.

ADP (Option B): Involved in cellular energy balance but has no direct signalling role in the RAS pathway.

Calcium (Option D): Acts as an intracellular second messenger in various pathways but is not involved in RAS-mediated signalling.

questions.text: The Philadelphia chromosome seen in chronic myelocytic leukaemia (CML) results from which of the following molecular mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chromosomal translocation involves the exchange of genetic material between nonhomologous chromosomes. This event can result in the formation of fusion genes with oncogenicpotential.
  • In chronic myelocytic leukaemia (CML), the Philadelphia chromosome is the result of a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, designated as t(9;22)(q34;q11).
  • This translocation results in the fusion of the BCR gene (located on chromosome 22) with the ABL gene (located on chromosome 9), forming a BCR-ABL fusion gene that encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase, thereby promoting uncontrolled cell proliferation.

Explanation of other options:

Gene amplification (Option B): Involves increased copies of a gene, seen in tumors with drug resistance, but not the mechanism in CML.

Promoter insertion (Option C): Seen in retroviral oncogenesis, where a strong viral promoter activates a proto-oncogene.

Enhancer insertion (Option D): Also viral in origin, activates transcription from distant sites; not implicated in the Philadelphia chromosome.

questions.text: Which of the following is a tumour suppressor gene?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rb (Retinoblastoma protein) is a classic example of a tumour suppressor gene.
  • It regulates the G1-S checkpoint of the cell cycle by binding to and inhibiting the transcription factor E2F.
  • Mutation or inactivation of the Rb gene removes this inhibition, resulting in uncontrolled cell division, a hallmark of tumor formation.
  • Loss-of-function mutations in tumour suppressor genes are typically recessive, requiring both alleles to be inactivated for a phenotypic effect.

Explanation of other options:

Ras (Option A): A proto-oncogene; when mutated, it becomes an oncogene involved in signal transduction (GTPase activity).

Abl (Option B): Encodes tyrosine kinase; forms the BCR-ABL fusion gene in CML, an example of oncogene activation.

Myc (Option C): A transcription factor oncogene associated with Burkitt lymphoma and other malignancies.

Key takeaways:

choices.text: A Mutation in one allele is sufficient
The oncogenic effect is due to the gain of function of a protein that signals cell division

questions.text: All of the following are characteristic features of oncogenes, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Strong tissue preference -not a characteristic feature of oncogenes.
  • Oncogenes typically do not show tissue-specific
  • A single oncogene can be associated with tumours arising from various tissues, and its effect is largely context-dependent, rather than tissue-specific.
  • In contrast, Tumour suppressor genes often demonstrate strong tissue preference with respect to the type of cancers in which they are found (eg, mutations in the RB gene result in retinoblastoma)

Explanation of other options:

Mutation in one allele is sufficient (Option A): Oncogenes act dominantly, i.e., mutation in just one allele is enough to induce oncogenic transformation.

In contrast, tumour suppressor genes require the mutation of both alleles for functional loss.

Oncogenic effect is due to gain of function (Option B): Mutations in proto-oncogenes typically result in gain-of-function, promoting uncontrolled cell division and proliferation.

Mutations are never inherited (Option D): Most oncogene mutations are somatic, meaning they are acquired, not inherited. In contrast, mutations in tumour suppressor genes (e.g., BRCA1, RB) can be germline/inherited.

questions.text: Which of the following gene associated with colorectal carcinogenesis is involved in tyrosine kinase signalling?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

K-RAS encodes a protein involved in tyrosine kinase signaling, especially within the MAP kinase pathway, which plays a central role in cell growth and proliferation.

In colorectal cancer, mutations in K-RAS lead to constitutive activation of downstream signaling, promoting oncogenesis.

Explanation of other options:

Beta-catenin (Option A): Encodes a structural protein in adherens junctions, important for epithelial cell integrity. It is a part of the WNT signaling pathway, not tyrosine kinase signaling.

P53 (Option C): Acts as a tumour suppressor gene, induced in response to DNA damage, functioning as a transcription factor.

BAX (Option D): A pro-apoptotic gene that promotes programmed cell death. It does not participate in tyrosine kinase pathways.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a growth inhibitory factor?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Transforming Growth Factor Beta (TGF-β) is a well-characterized growth inhibitory factor.
  • It inhibits proliferation in a wide variety of cell types and plays a key role in maintaining tissue homeostasis.
  • TGF-β can exert both stimulatory and inhibitory effects, depending on the cell type and biological context.

Explanation of other options:

Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF) (Option A): Primarily acts as a mitogenic stimulant, promoting the growth and proliferation of epidermal and epithelial cells.

Transforming Growth Factor Alpha (TGF-α) (Option B): Has similar action to EGF; it stimulates cell proliferation, not inhibition.

Fibroblast Growth Factors (FGFs) (Option C): A family of growth factors that promote proliferation and differentiation in various cell types, especially mesenchymal and epithelial cells.
